titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Grand Duchess Ksenii͡a Aleksandrovna papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Michael Jakobson

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-05-26T10:21-0700

change.item: Revised to update access notes by Sarah Patton.

PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::80011::Kseniia Aleksandrovna, Grand Duchess of Russia Papers)//EN" "kseniia.xml" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

physdesc.extent: 16 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize box, 1 cubic foot box, 1 envelope

did.abstract: Correspondence, diaries, printed matter, and photographs relating to events in Russia before, during, and after the Russian Revolution, and to Russian Imperial family matters. Includes letters of Nicholas II and his mother, Mariia Feodorovna.

origination.label: Creator
origination.persname: Ksenii͡a Aleksandrovna, Grand Duchess of Russia.

origination.label: Contributor
origination.persname: Marīi͡a Ḟeodorovna, Empress, consort of Alexander III, Emperor of Russia, 1847-1928.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Boxes 12-13 may not be used without permission of the Archivist; use copies are available in Boxes 6-8. Remainder of collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Grand Duchess Ksenii͡a Aleksandrovna papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1980, with an increment of additional materials acquired in 2002.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Born to Mariia Feodorovna, Princess Dagmara of Denmark and Alexander III, Emperor of Russia
Married Aleksandr Mikhailovich, Grand Duke of Russia (Sandro)
Gave birth to Irina Aleksandrovna, Princess of Russia
Gave birth to Andrei Aleksandrovich, Prince of Russia
Gave birth to Fedor Aleksandrovich, Prince of Russia
Gave birth to Nikita Aleksandrovich, Prince of Russia
Gave birth to Dimitrii Aleksandrovich, Prince of Russia
Gave birth to Rostislav Aleksandrovich, Prince of Russia
Gave birth to Vasilii Aleksandrovich, Prince of Russia

Traveled with her children to Ai-Todor, the estate in the Crimea that belonged to her husband Aleksandr Mikhailovich (the latter, Kseniia's mother Mariia Feodorovna, and her sister Olga with her husband had left for Ai-Todor on the 23rd). They were kept there under house arrest

Transferred, along with the family members mentioned above as well as her son-in-law Felix Yusupov and her granddaughter, to Dulber, the fortress-like estate also in the Crimea belonging to Grand Duke Petr Nikolaevich. (The latter and his brother, Grand Duke Nikolai Nikolaevich, their wives, and Peter's children, had gone to Duil'ber after the fall of the monarchy.)

Sailed from Yalta (along with several members of her family, her mother Mariia Feodorovna, and other relatives) on the HMS Marlborough, sent by her cousin George V, King of England (the Allied fleet had arrived in the Crimea at the end of 1918)
Made frequent visits to her mother in Denmark, until the death of Mariia Feodorovna in 1928
Lived in Frogmore Cottage, Windsor Palace
Lived in Wilderness House, Hampton Court, again as a guest of the British royal family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Kseniia Aleksandrovna were deposited in the Hoover Institution by her family in 1980, under the supervision of her son the late Vasili Romanoff, who served as honorary curator of the Hoover Institution Archives Imperial Russian Collection.

Of particular interest are her diaries, covering the period from January 1916 to March 1919, the day before she left the Crimea for England. Also significant is the correspondence between her and her brother, Emperor Nicholas II, and between him and their mother, Empress Mariia Feodorovna. Those original diaries and letters, in Boxes 12-13, may not be used without permission of the Archivist, but use copies are available in Boxes 6-8.

Other diaries of note are those of Mariia Feodorovna (in Box 9) and of Kseniia's brother, Grand Duke Mikhail Aleksandrovich (in Box 11), as well as a diary presumed to have been kept for the crown prince Aleksei by his French and English tutors (in Box 8).

The bulk of the collection relates to Mariia Feodorovna, consisting of extensive correspondence with her daughter Kseniia (Boxes 1-6) and with others (Boxes 8-9), and of condolence letters upon her death in 1928 (Boxes 9-10).

The increment consists mainly of correspondence with family members in the United States and Europe, and various royal figures from the United Kingdom, Denmark, Sweden, Germany, Greece, Bulgaria, Romania, and Yugoslavia. Correspondence includes handwritten (mostly unidentified) letters on political, social, religious, educational, and economic conditions in Russia. The increment also contains a number of remarkable prints depicting members of the royal family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, diaries, menus, poems, reports, visitors' book, clippings, and other printed matter, arranged alphabetically by subject. Consists mostly of material relating to Mariia Feodorovna, consort of Alexander III, Emperor of Russia.

did.unittitle: Aleksei Nikolaevich, Czarevitch, son of Nicholas II, Emperor of Russia,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Diary presumably kept by his tutors, relating to his daily activities for January and February 1917, written both in French and English. Also lists birth and baptism dates of Romanov family members.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Boxes 12-13 may not be used without permission of the Archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Original diaries of Kseniia Aleksandrovna, 1916 January - 1919 March (use copies in Boxes 6-7); original correspondence between her and Nicholas II, Emperor of Russia, 1917-1918 (use copies in Box 6); original letters from Nicholas II to Mariia Feodorovna, 1916-1918 (use copies in Box 8).

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 12 may not be used without permission of the Archivist (use copies in Boxes 6-7).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 drawings, 1 painting, 14 postcards, 83 prints, 6 prints of paintings

did.unittitle: Depicting Vincent Cardinal; members of the Danish royal family; members of the Russian imperial family officers and men of the Russian army, as well as scenes of their activities in campaigns against Austrian troops during World War I, as well as the war's effect on lives, property, and the environment; scenes in Finland, including a monument to Alexander III; a cottage in France; HMS Marlborough as well as a silver bugle located on the ship; churches and other buildings in Russia; the tomb of Giulietta in Verona, Italy; and miscellaneous personalities and objects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical materials, correspondence, subject file, photographs, and postcards, arranged by physical form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes one print of Prince Aleksandr Romanoff (son of Prince Nikita), King Umberto of Italy, and Mother Martha; photograph taken in the grounds of Wilderness House, the home of Grand Duchess Kseniia - one of the only recorded photographs of Mother Martha, the companion of Grand Duchess Kseniia for many years. See also: correspondence.

did.unittitle: Postcards - five Finnish postcards depicting Russian military personnel,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Original letters to Kseniia displayed in sleeves on oversize board. Dates given according to both the Julian and Gregorian calendars. The Julian calendar was in use in Russia until 1918, rather than the Gregorian calendar of the West. In the 20th century the former was thirteen days behind the latter.
